page.title: APM College of Business and Communication

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: bachelor degree → bachelor's degree using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (11406)
revision.text:
'''APM College of Business and Communication''' is an Australian private business college that offers both tertiary education and vocational education and training.<ref>{{cite web|title=APM College of Business and Communication listing in the University Admission Centre guide|url=http://www.uac.edu.au/documents/undergraduate/institutions/apm.pdf|website=www.uac.edu.au|publisher=Universities Admission Centre|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Jen|title=University admissions centre opens doors to private college applications|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/education/university-admissions-centre-opens-doors-to-private-college-applications-20120617-20i5w.html|website=www.smh.com.au|publisher=Fairfax Media|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> The college first opened in 1986 as the APM Training Institute in [[St Leonards, Sydney]].
The college is owned by education provider [[Think Education]], itself part of the [[Laureate International Universities]] group. Think Education was previously owned by [[SEEK Learning]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SEEK|url=http://www.theage.com.au/business/markets/quotes/announcement/SEK/seek-limited/1463316|website=www.theage.com.au|publisher=Fairfax Media|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
== Courses == The college offers bachelor's degree and diploma courses specialising in Business Management, Public Relations, Marketing and Event Management. Course are offered on campus and online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Courses|url=http://www.apm.edu.au/courses|website=www.apm.edu.au|publisher=Think Education|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
== Campuses == The college has two campuses in Sydney ([[The Rocks, Sydney|The Rocks]]) and Brisbane ([[Fortitude Valley]]). The campus at The Rocks was opened in February 2015 and is shared exclusively with partner college [[William Blue College of Hospitality Management]], while Brisbane is also shared with the chain's William Blue College of Hospitality Management as well as Think Education partners [[Australasian College of Natural Therapies]], Australian National College of Beauty, [[Jansen Newman Institute]], [[Billy Blue College of Design]] and [[CATC Design School]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Campuses|url=http://www.think.edu.au/colleges/see-all-campuses|website=www.think.edu.au|publisher=Think Education|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.apm.edu.au APM College of Business and Communication website]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Coord|-33.8356|151.2077 |type:landmark_region:US|display=title}}
[[Category:Business schools in Australia]]

revision.text:
'''Aisling Maria Burnand''', [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 22 December 1964) is a British business executive and consultant. In 2009 she joined [[Cancer Research UK]] as Executive Director of Policy & Public Affairs.<ref name=CRUK/> in 2013 she became chief executive of the Association of Medical Research Charities.<ref>[https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/02107400/officers Association of Medical Research Charities profile], companieshouse.gov.uk; accessed 24 April 2016.</ref>
==Career== Burnand worked as head of international [[media relations]] for [[Rhône-Poulenc]] in Paris, then as a director at the Rowland Company, a [[London]]-based public affairs consultancy.<ref> [http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/97064/ Burnand to bioindustry body public affairs role], [[Campaign (magazine)|''Campaign '']], 18 September 1998.</ref>
She joined the UK BioIndustry Association as its first Director of Public Affairs in 1998, when the UK [[biotechnology]] industry was in its infancy.<ref name=interview2007>[http://business.scotsman.com/biotechnology/Testing-times-for-biotech-champion.3347559.jp Testing times for biotech champion], interview in ''[[The Scotsman]]'', 11 February 2007.</ref> The Association now represents more than three hundred UK biotech companies. In 2001 Burnand became Deputy Chief Executive, and from 2003 until December 2009 she was Chief Executive. She was succeeded by Nigel Gaymond.<ref name=BIA2009>[http://www.bioindustry.org/biodocuments/BIA_Annual_Review_2009.pdf BIA Annual Review 2009]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>[http://www.nzbio.org.nz/default.aspx?page=20&news=4272 New CEO of UK BioIndustry Association announced] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515005706/http://nzbio.org.nz/default.aspx?page=20&news=4272 |date=2010-05-15 }}, NZBIO, 10 December 2009.</ref>
At the BIA, Burnand lobbied on behalf of [[stem cell]] research, and supported the passage of the [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005]], which gives greater protection for [[medical research]]ers from [[animal rights]] extremists and other threats.<ref name=MBE>[http://www.mednous.com/appointment/bioindustry-association-executive-awarded-mbe BioIndustry Association executive awarded MBE], MedNous.com, 18 June 2007</ref> She also had to reassure the public about medicines based on [[monoclonal antibodies]] when six volunteers suffered severse adverse reactions during a [[clinical trial]] at [[Northwick Park Hospital]] in 2006.<ref name=interview2007/>
In 2007 she was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] for services to science.<ref name=MBE/>
She joined [[Cancer Research UK]] in 2009. As Executive Director of Policy & Public Affairs, she has responsibility for the charity's policies on cancer, science and charity issues, seeking along with others to influence politicians and civil servants on issues of importance to cancer patients.<ref name=CRUK>[http://aboutus.cancerresearchuk.org/who-we-are/how-we-are-governed/executive-board Profile], Cancer Research UK; retrieved 23 December 2010.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Anita Jose''' (born 1960-70s) is an [[India]]n born educator, business strategist, Professor of Management at [[Hood College]], and essayist in the field of business management and policy.<ref name="GroupedRef1">http://www.mediate.com/people/personprofile.cfm?auid=720</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dla.mil/do/resolve/eeo_med_prog.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927170007/http://www.dla.mil/do/resolve/eeo_med_prog.asp |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
== Life and work == Jose was born in India, and emigrate to the United States. In the 1990s she received her doctorate from the [[University of North Texas]] and her MBA and MMGT from the [[University of Dallas]].<ref name="GroupedRef1" />
By 1999 she had started her academic career and was assistant professor at [[Hood College]].<ref>Jose & Thibodeaux (1999)</ref> By 2017 she is Professor of Management and Director of the MBA Program at [[Hood College]].<ref name="GroupedRef1" /> She is member of the Editorial/Review Board of the ''Journal of American Society of Business and Behavioral Sciences,''the ''[[Society for the Advancement of Management|Society for the Advancement of Management Conference]],'' and the ''SAM Advanced Management Journal.''
Her research has included a focus in the areas of organizational strategy, international management, and business ethics/corporate social responsibility. She has done extensive research in EEOC programs and workplace conflict resolution with the Center of conflict Resolution at [[Salisbury University]].<ref>http://www.conflict-resolution.org/sitebody/research/default.htm</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://144.175.41.15/academics/departments.cfm?pid%3Ddepartments_economicsFacultyJose.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703111758/http://144.175.41.15/academics/departments.cfm?pid=departments_economicsFacultyJose.html |archivedate=2011-07-03 |df= }}</ref> She has over 15 essays publications in professional journals and is a guest presenter and speaker at many conferences.<ref name="GroupedRef2">http://www.hood.edu/academics/departments/economics-and-management/faculty/Anita-Jose.html</ref> Her commentary has appeared in newspapers and television throughout the U.S and in India.<ref name="GroupedRef2" /> Her research, reports, and articles have appeared in varied publications like the ''Journal of Business Ethics'', ''Southern Law Journal, Business Intelligence'', and ''Advances in Industrial Relations Research''.<ref name="GroupedRef1" />
== Selected publications == * McDermott, P., Obar, R., Jose, A., & Bowers, M. (2000). ''An evaluation of the equal employment opportunity commission mediation program.'' EEOC Order, (9/0900), 7632.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eeoc.gov/mediate/report/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826032907/http://eeoc.gov/mediate/report/index.html |archivedate=2009-08-26 |df= }}</ref>
;Articles, a selection * Jose, Anita, and Mary S. Thibodeaux. "Institutionalization of ethics: The perspective of managers." ''Journal of Business Ethics'' 22.2 (1999): 133-143.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=25074196 |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/25074196?uid=3739256&uid=2&uid=4&sid=21102076511213 |title=Institutionalization of Ethics: The Perspective of Managers |deadurl=no |accessdate=5 June 2013 |volume=22 |pages=133–143}}</ref> * Jose, Anita, and Shang-Mei Lee. "[http://www.ucipfg.com/Repositorio/MLGA/MLGA-01/BLOQUE-ACADEMICO/Unidad-4/lecturas/Environmental_Reporting_of_Global_Corporations.pdf Environmental reporting of global corporations: A content analysis based on website disclosures]." ''Journal of Business Ethics'' 72.4 (2007): 307-321.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.hood.edu/Academics/Departments/Economics-and-Management/Faculty/Anita-Jose.html Anita Jose; Professor of Management; Director, M.B.A. Program] Hood College.
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''Antwerpsche Diamantkring''' was established in 1928 in [[Antwerp]], Belgium, to become the first diamond bourse worldwide that is dedicated exclusively to rough diamonds trade.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.awdc.be/en/20th-century |title=The history of the Antwerp Diamond Center |publisher=Antwerp World Diamond Centre}}</ref>
It is a member of the [[World Federation of Diamond Bourses]].
85% of the world’s diamond supply is traded in Antwerp, and in particular in the Antwerpsche Diamantkring.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/inside-antwerps-secret-glittering-ultra-secure-diamond-hq-where-85-of-the-worlds-supply-changes-hands |title=Inside Antwerp’s secret, glittering, ultra-secure diamond HQ where 85% of the world’s supply changes hands |newspaper=National Post |date=December 9, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belgium/10502563/Antwerps-secret-heart-of-the-31bn-global-diamond-trade.html |title=Antwerp's secret heart of the £31bn global diamond trade |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=December 7, 2013}}</ref>
==Presidents of the Board of Directors== * 1929-1957 Gustave Garitte * 1957-1961 Frans Beukelaar * 1961-1972 [[Israel Beck]] * 1973-1979 Michel Fraenkel * 1979-1987 Sammy Hutterer * 1987-1999 Isi Beck * 1999-2003 Gerson Goldschmidt * 2003-2012 David Wahl * 2012- Alfred (Freddy) Inzlicht
==Rough Diamond Day== The Rough Diamond Day is a biannual international event dedicated to rough diamonds trade, organized by the Antwerpsche Diamantkring.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.diamonds.net/News/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=48488&ArticleTitle=Antwerpsche+Diamantkring+Hosts+Rough+Diamond+Day |title=Antwerpsche Diamantkring Hosts Rough Diamond Day |website=Rapapport Diamonds.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.awdc.be/en/antwerpsche-diamantkring-orga |title=Antwerpsche Diamantkring organizes second Rough Diamond Day |website=Antwerp World Diamond Center}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.diamantkring.org// Antwerpsche Diamantkring website]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Antwerpsche Diamantkring}} [[Category:Business organisations based in Belgium]] [[Category:Companies based in Antwerp]] [[Category:Diamond exchanges]] [[Category:Commodity exchanges]] [[Category:Companies established in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Belgium]]
{{Belgium-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Brett Gosper''' (born 21 June 1959 in Melbourne, Australia {{citation needed|date=January 2016}}) is CEO of [[World Rugby]] and a former advertising executive and rugby union player.
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Brett Gosper | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image =BrettGosper.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1959|06|21}} | birth_place = Melbourne, Australia | disappeared_date = <!-- {{Disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = London, UK | nationality = Australian | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = Elizabeth Gosper | partner = | children = 3 | parents = [[Kevan Gosper]], Jillian Mary Galwey | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }}
==Early life== Gosper was educated at [[Scotch College, Melbourne]] and [[Monash University]]; Faculties of Law and Economics. {{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==Advertising career== In 1981, Gosper began his advertising career as graduate trainee with [[Ogilvy & Mather]] in Melbourne and Brisbane, Australia. On being offered a place with the Racing Club rugby team in Paris he transferred to Ogilvy & Mather Paris in 1982 where he would become Group Account Director in 1986. {{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}
In 1989 Gosper left Ogilvy & Mather to go on to become Deputy managing director of France's 3rd largest agency BDDP Paris (now [[TBWA]]) in 1992. While at BDDP Gosper led a number of international account wins including [[TAG Heuer]] watches for whom he wrote the concept of their first worldwide campaign "Don't Crack Under Pressure". Gosper led the successful pitch for [[BMW]] in Germany in 1993 which led to him spending a year in Germany launching the BDDP Frankfurt office.<ref>{{cite web|last=Staff |first=Adweek |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/frankfurt-agencies-play-musical-execs-bddps-raid-leaves-dmbb-scrambling-ke |title=Frankfurt Agencies Play 'Musical Execs': BDDP's Raid Leaves DMB&B Scrambling to Keep P&G Satisfied By Rosemarie TotzaueFRANKFURT – BDDP's raid of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles' executive muscle for client BMW has |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1994 Gosper was recruited by Havas to relaunch [[Euro RSCG]]'s struggling entities in London as Chief Executive Officer of newly branded Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper. {{citation needed|date=October 2015}} For almost a decade Gosper led the agency on an industry acclaimed run of new business acquisition that included [[Abbey National]], [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]], [[Bass Brewery]], [[Cadbury]], [[Coca-Cola]]'s Atlanta roster, [[Commission for Racial Equality]], [[Credit Suisse]], [[Evian]], [[Häagen-Dazs]], [[Intel]], [[Microsoft]], [[Philips]] (Gosper was the author of the worldwide brand slogan "Let's Make Things Better"), [[Reckitt Benckiser]] and [[The Independent]].
The rise of Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper to number one in the Campaign Magazine's Business Performance League ensured the agency a Top 10 London agency ranking and several years as finalist in [[Ad Age]]'s International Agency of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.highbeam.com/436953/article-1G1-15880744/euro-rscg-retools-london-office-new-ceo-named |title=Euro RSCG retools London office, new CEO named. (Brett Gosper) (Brief Article) | HighBeam Business: Arrive Prepared |publisher=Business.highbeam.com |date=14 November 1994 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2003, Gosper moved to New York and [[McCann Erickson]] as CEO of their flagship New York office.<ref>{{cite web|author=Glen Mutel |url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/187960/ |title=CLOSE-UP: NEWSMAKER – BRETT GOSPER. Brett Gosper sets out to make his mark on a third continent – Brand Republic News |publisher=Brandrepublic.com |date=15 August 2003 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2004, Gosper was appointed President of [[TBWA]] New York Group (comprising TBWA\Chiat\Day New York, Tequila New York, and Brand Architecture International). Gosper led the successful pitch for the newly merged [[Sprint-Nextel]] business. With billings of $800 million, it was the biggest marketing services pitch that year in the USA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/people-players/tbwa-lures-mccann-exec-head-unit/40904/ |title=TBWA LURES MCCANN EXEC TO HEAD UNIT | People & Players – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=19 August 2004 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/20/business/the-media-business-advertising-addenda-manager-at-mccann-is-leaving-for-tbwa.html |title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING – ADDENDA; Manager at McCann Is Leaving for TBWA – New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=20 August 2004 |accessdate=29 January 2012 |first=Stuart |last=Elliott}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/room-nearer-top-gets-gosper-tbwa-74377 |title=Room Nearer the Top Gets Gosper to TBWA |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2005, [[McCann Erickson]] re-hired Gosper as President of McCann Erickson USA. During the time of Gosper's leadership at McCann, the agency's new business wins included [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]], [[Staples Inc.|Staples]], [[Smith Barney]], [[Verizon]], [[US Army]], [[Viagra]], [[Lunesta]], [[Weight Watchers]], [[USA Today]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/gospers-second-thoughts-give-him-second-chance-81743 |title=Gosper's Second Thoughts Give Him A Second Chance |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/gosper-rejoin-mccann-president-81666 |title=Gosper to Rejoin McCann as President |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
Back in London since 2007, Gosper became the Chief Executive Officer of McCann Erickson Europe, Middle East and Africa, until March 2011. Gosper was also a member of the McCann Worldgroup Executive Committee, and Board Executive responsible for European-based global accounts including [[L'Oreal]], [[Nestle]], [[Unilever]], [[Sony Ericsson]], [[InterContinental Hotels Group]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Mark Sweney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/02/citynews.advertising |title=Brett Gosper returns to London | Media | MediaGuardian |publisher=Guardian |date= 2 May 2007|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mccannworldgroup.com/2011/03/gustavo-martinez-joins-mccann-worldgroup-as-european-president/ |title=Gustavo Martinez Joins McCann Worldgroup as European President |publisher=McCANN Worldgroup |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
==Rugby career==
===Early club career in Australia===
Gosper begun his first grade rugby career in Melbourne in 1978 with the Melbourne Rugby Union Football Club. {{citation needed|date=October 2015}} In 1979 at the age of 20, Gosper was named captain. In 1980, he represented the State of Victoria against the New Zealand All Blacks.
Gosper moved to Brisbane in 1981 where he joined GPS Old Boys and the Queensland rugby union squad.
===Racing Club de France (1981–1990)===
Gosper left Australia aged 22 when recruited by France's oldest rugby club, the Racing Club de France (now [[Racing 92]]) in Paris, where he played from 1981 to 1990. The team was also famous at the time for wearing pink bow ties in the 1987 and 1990 finals of the French Championship.
===International career===
Gosper played trials for the [[Australia national rugby union team]] tours in 1979 (Argentina) and 1981 (United Kingdom). He represented the Australian Under 21 Rugby Union team in 1980, versus New Zealand at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]].<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t8RYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v5IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3648,3140334&dq=brett+gosper+rugby&hl=en</ref><ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Tp1WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=guYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4596,4932897&dq=brett+gosper+rugby&hl=en</ref>
Gosper represented a French selection ("Séléction Du Manoir") against British [[Barbarian F.C.]] in 1982 at the [[Parc des Princes]].
Gosper was selected by the French [[Barbarian Rugby Club]] to play against the touring All Blacks at La Rochelle in 1986. Gosper was captain of the Italian side at the Monaco Sevens in 1986 at the [[Stade Louis II]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barbarian-rugby-club.com/joueur/Brett-Gosper/218 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408163231/http://barbarian-rugby-club.com/joueur/Brett-Gosper/218 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 April 2016 |title=Brett Gosper – Ils sont Barbarians |publisher=Barbarian Rugby Club |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012 }}</ref>
===Rugby honours=== *Racing Club de France: Best Club Player, 1987. *Melbourne Rugby Football Club: Best Club Player, 1978-1979-1980.
===World Rugby=== In July 2012, Gosper was appointed as the chief executive of the International Rugby Board, now called [[World Rugby]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/18938451|title=Australian Brett Gosper appointed as new IRB chief executive|accessdate=21 July 2012}}</ref>
As CEO, Gosper has overseen Rugby's successful return to the [[Olympic Games]] (after 92 years absence) in Rio in 2016 <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldrugby.org/news/204417?lang=en|title=Game-changing Olympic return draws at least 16.83 million new fans to rugby|accessdate=14 November 2016}}</ref> as well as a record-breaking [[Rugby World Cup]] in England in 2015. With 2.47 million tickets sold and commercial and ticketing revenues in excess of £600 million, the [[2015 Rugby World Cup]] generated over £160 million in total surplus to [[World Rugby]] for reinvestment in the global game. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/rugby/world-rugby-announces-astonishing-record-financial-results-from-2015/news-story/4d77fe529beb11c69ff42fd3efd31df3|title=World Rugby announces astonishing record financial results from 2015|accessdate=16 December 2016}}</ref>
Gosper also led the repositioning and rebranding of the former 'International Rugby Board' to its current name; [[World Rugby]], which was designed to raise the profile of World Rugby's various 15s and 7s tournament assets and properties. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldrugby.org/news/37400?lang=en|title=IRB becomes World Rugby as new brand is launched|accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> The rebranding has contributed to the dramatic increase in World Rugby's social media presence as one of the most extensive and engaged of the Olympic sports federations.
==Personal life== Gosper is the son of International Olympic Committee member and former Vice-President, [[Kevan Gosper]] and brother of Dean Gosper who is a member of the Executive Board of the International Ski Federation (FIS).
He is married with three children. {{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gosper, Brett}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian rugby union players]] [[Category:Australian sports executives and administrators]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Racing 92 players]]

page.title: Chartered Institute of Credit Management (formerly Institute of Credit Management)

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=February 2014}} '''The Institute of Credit Management''' (ICM) (now known as the [[Chartered Institute of Credit Management]]) is a United Kingdom-based professional body representing credit professionals. It was founded in 1939.<ref>[http://www.thepandagroup.co.uk/news/14-the-icm-british-credit-awards-2015 The ICM British Credit Awards 2015] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229004635/http://www.thepandagroup.co.uk/news/14-the-icm-british-credit-awards-2015 |date=December 29, 2014 }}</ref>
The ICM is the largest professional credit management organisation in [[Europe]] and has some 8,700 members who hold appointments throughout industry and commerce and also in certain related activities such as: *debt collections *credit reporting *credit insurance and *[[Insolvency Practitioner|insolvency practice]].
The ICM is a [[company limited by guarantee]] and its goal is to raise the professional standards operating in credit management, and to increase awareness of its importance as a management tool.
The ICM has produced a series of guides called Managing Cashflow for the [[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]], in partnership with the UK’s leading business organisations.<ref>[http://www.creditmanagement.org.uk/bisguides.htm Credit Management Matters : BIS Guides]</ref>
The Institute was granted a Royal Charter in January 2015, and is now known as the Chartered Institute of Credit Management.<ref>[http://www.cicm.com/icm-starts-new-year-royal-approval/ CICM Press release 1 January 2015]</ref><ref>[http://www.cicm.com/cicm-unveils-royal-charter/ CICM Press Release 11 March 2015 CICM unveils Royal Charter]</ref>
==Aims== The ICM's role is to:
* Set professional standards * Test and assesses those who wish to become ICM members * Organise specialist education and training relevant to the needs of its members * Provide an appropriate range of services to allow credit managers to keep up to date * Consult with and make recommendations to the [[Government]], [[European Commission]], other professional bodies and trade associations.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.icm.org.uk ICM website] *[http://www.icmk.org Institute of Credit management Kenya]

{{No footnotes|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Christopher Polhem | image = Christopher_Polhem_painted_by_Johan_Henrik_Scheffel_1741.jpg | caption = Christopher Polhem'', [[Johan Henrik Scheffel]], 1741. | birth_date = 18 December 1661 | birth_place = [[Tingstäde]], [[Gotland]], Sweden | death_date = {{death date and age|1751|8|30|1661|12|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | residence = Sweden | nationality = [[Swedish people|Swedish]] | field = Physics, Mechanics | work_institution = | alma_mater = [[Uppsala University]]
[[University of Harderwijk]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = [[Göta Canal]]
Various inventions | prizes = | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Christopher Polhammar''' (18 December 1661 – 30 August 1751){{cite web|title=Christopher Polhem|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Christopher-Polhem|website=www.britannica.com|accessdate=30 October 2017}}, better known as '''Christopher Polhem''' ({{Audio|sv-christopher_polhem.ogg|listen}}), which he took after his [[ennoblement]], was a Swedish scientist, inventor and industrialist. He made significant contributions to the economic and industrial development of Sweden, particularly mining. ==Biography== Polhem (Polhammar) was born on the island of Gotland in the small village of [[Tingstäde]], situated northeast of [[Visby]]. Originally the Polhem family came from Austria to [[Pomerania]], Germany, from where his father, Wolf Christoph Polhammer traded with [[Visby]], where he would eventually settle down to become a skipper. In Stockholm he attended a German school until the age of 8 when his father died. His mother, Christina Eriksdotter Schening from [[Vadstena]], Östergötland remarried. As a result of conflicts with his stepfather, his private tuition was no longer paid for and Polhem was sent to live with his uncle in Stockholm. He took a job as a farmhand on Vansta, a property in [[Södertörn]], Stockholm. He quickly rose to the position of supervisor, being responsible for supervision and accounting, for which he was well suited by his affinity for mathematics. He worked at Vansta for ten years, during which period he constructed a workshop where he made tools, repaired and constructed simple machinery to earn money. Hungering for knowledge within his fields of interest, mathematics and mechanics, he soon realized that he would get no further without learning Latin. Self-studies were attempted, but given up; Polhem realized he needed a tutor. In exchange for constructing a complex clock, he was given Latin lessons by a local vicar. Word of Polhem's mechanical skill spread quickly and a member of the clergy wrote the professor of mathematics at Uppsala University, Anders Spole to recommend Polhem. Spole, grandfather of [[Anders Celsius]], presented two broken clocks to Polhem and offered to let him study under him if he could repair them, Polhem repaired the clocks with no difficulty and began recovering years of lost education in 1687, at the age of 26. He married [[Maria Hoffman]] in 1691, together they had two children, Gabriel and Emerentia. In 1716 he was [[ennoblement|ennobled]] in gratitude of his services to the nation by the king and changed his name from ''Polhammar'' to ''Polheim'', which he later changed to ''Polhem''. He and his son [[Gabriel Polhem]] were both elected members of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] in 1739, the year the Academy was founded. Polhem died of natural causes in 1751 in Stockholm. == Career == === Industrial === [[Image:Petrus Astronomus Astronomical clock in Uppsala Cathedral.jpg|thumb|250px|right|16th century woodcut from the ''History'' of [[Olaus Magnus]], purportedly depicting the astronomical clock in [[Uppsala Cathedral]].]] According to Polhem's [[autobiography]], the event that marked the beginning of his career was the successful repair of the unfinished [[medieval]] (16th century) [[astronomical clock]] by [[Petrus Astronomus]] at [[Uppsala Cathedral]], which had remained unfinished and broken for more than a century. In 1690 Polhem was appointed to improve upon the current [[mining operations]] of Sweden. His contribution was a construction for lifting and transporting [[ore]] from mines, a process that was rather risky and inefficient at the time. The construction consisted of a track system for lifting the ore, as opposed to wires; the construction was powered entirely by a [[water wheel]]. Human labor needed was limited to loading the containers. Being new and [[revolutionary]], word of Polhem's work reached the reigning king, [[Charles XI]] who was so impressed with the work that he assigned him to improve Sweden's main mining operation; the [[Falun]] Copper mine. [[Image:Stora stöten.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Great Copper Mountain|Falun copper mine]] as it looks today.]] Funded by the Swedish mining authority, Polhem traveled throughout Europe, studying mechanical development. He returned to Sweden in 1697 to establish ''laboratorium mechanicum'' in [[Stockholm]], a facility for the training of engineers, as well as a laboratory for testing and exhibiting his designs. It has since become the prestigious [[The Royal Institute of Technology|KTH Royal Institute of Technology]], whose history began with king [[Charles XI]] and his praise for Christopher Polhem for his mining efforts. His greatest achievement was an automated factory powered entirely by water; automation was very unusual at the time. Built in 1699 in [[Hedemora Municipality|Stjärnsund]], the factory produced a number of products, deriving from the idea that Sweden should export fewer raw materials and process them within their own borders instead. The factory was a failure; it met great resistance among workers who feared they would be replaced by machinery. Eventually most of the factory was destroyed in a fire in 1734, leaving only the part of the factory that produced clocks. The factory continued producing clocks, known for their high quality and low price. Although the popularity of the clocks diminished during the beginning of the 19th century, clock-making continues to this day at Stjärnsund, still producing around twenty clocks of the Polhem design per year. Another product from the factory was the Scandinavian padlock ("Polhem locks", Swedish: Polhemslås), essentially the first design of the variation of [[padlock]]s common today. Economically, the factory was unfeasible, but the king at the time, [[Charles XII]], was supportive and gave Polhem freedom from taxes to encourage his efforts. The factory of Stjärnsund was visited by one of his contemporaries, [[Carl Linnaeus]], who wrote about the factory in his diaries as ''Nothing is more optimistic than Stjärnsund'' (''"Intet är spekulativare än Stjärnsund"''). Polhem also contributed to the construction of [[Göta Canal]], a canal connecting the east and west coasts of Sweden. Together with [[Charles XII of Sweden]], he planned the construction of parts of the canal, particularly the [[canal lock]]s in the 18th century; it was not to be finished until 1832, long after his death. Other major contributions made by Polhem were the constructions of [[dry dock]]s, [[dam]]s and as mentioned before, [[canal lock]]s, which he designed together with his assistant and friend, [[Emanuel Swedenborg]]. ===Other fields=== Polhem was not only active within the field of mechanics, he actively wrote essays concerning [[medicine]], [[social criticism]], [[astronomy]], [[geology]] and [[economics]]. ==Other accomplishments== *Founder of [[Stjärnsunds manufakturverk]] *Can be found on the reverse of the former 500 Swedish kronor bank note, the front having a portrait of Charles XI of Sweden. *Has several schools named after him. *Has an award named after himself, the [[Polhem Prize]] (''[[:sv:Polhemspriset|Polhemspriset]]''), which is awarded to significant contributors to industry and construction engineering. *Reinvented the [[Cardan joint]] under the name of "Polhem knot" (''Polhemknut'') independently of [[Gerolamo Cardano]], the pioneer inventor. *Has a [[commemorative coin]] with his portrait on it, as well as a [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]], which can be found in Visby. *Organized machinery into a "mechanical alphabet" and provided examples of such. Of 80 models carved in wood, 32 are still in the collections of the National Museum of Science and Technology (Tekniska Museet) in Stockholm. Another 13 models of the "mechanical alphabet" are to be found in the Falun Mining Museum, Sweden. ==See also== *[[Emanuel Swedenborg]] ==References== ==Further reading== *Johnson, William A. ''Christopher Polhem, The Father of Swedish Technology'' (Hartford, CT Trinity College Press. 1963) ==External links== * [http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jbourj/money5.htm Polhem featured on the 500 Swedish kronor banknote.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060221022229/http://kanaler.arnholm.nu/creators.html "Kanalbyggare"] {{sv icon}} * [https://www.tekniskamuseet.se/en/learn-more/swedish-inventors/christopher-polhem-the-mechanical-alphabet/ Biography at Tekniska museet] {{sv icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051204113506/http://www.stjarnsund.com/polhem.htm Biography on the site of the town Stjärnsund] {{sv icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070705203701/http://www.stjarnsund.com/stjarnsundsur.htm History of watchmaking at Stjärnsund] {{sv icon}} * [http://www.numericana.com Numericana] entry on [http://www.numericana.com/arms/polhem.htm Polhem's coat of arms] which features the Pythagorean theorem. {{owl}} {{Swedish entrepreneurs}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Polhem, Christopher}} [[Category:1661 births]] [[Category:1751 deaths]] [[Category:People from Gotland]] [[Category:Swedish nobility]] [[Category:Swedish inventors]] [[Category:Swedish physicists]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Uppsala University alumni]] [[Category:University of Harderwijk alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:17th-century Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:18th-century Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Age of Liberty people]] [[Category:People of the Swedish Empire]] [[Category:18th-century Swedish scientists]]

[[File:Ice-cream-experiment-example.png|thumb|Example choice-based conjoint analysis survey with application to marketing (investigating preferences in ice-cream) on [https://run.conjoint.ly/study/163/3ewoipzq36 Conjoint.ly] ]]
{{'}}'''Conjoint analysis'''{{'}} is a survey-based statistical technique used in market research that helps determine how people value different attributes (feature, function, benefits) that make up an individual product or service.
The objective of conjoint analysis is to determine what combination of a limited number of attributes is most influential on respondent choice or decision making. A controlled set of potential products or services is shown to survey respondents and by analyzing how they make preferences between these products, the implicit valuation of the individual elements making up the product or service can be determined. These implicit valuations (utilities or part-worths) can be used to create market models that estimate market share, revenue and even profitability of new designs.
Conjoint originated in [[mathematical psychology]] and was developed by marketing professor [[Paul E. Green]] at the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]]. Other prominent conjoint analysis pioneers include professor [[V Srinivasan|V. "Seenu" Srinivasan]] of Stanford University who developed a linear programming (LINMAP) procedure for rank ordered data as well as a self-explicated approach, Richard Johnson who developed the Adaptive Conjoint Analysis technique in the 1980s<ref>{{cite conference | first = Richard M. | last = Johnson | title = History of ACA | booktitle = Proceedings of the Sawtooth Software Conference | date = September 2001 | location = Victoria, BC, Canada | url = http://www.sawtoothsoftware.com/support/technical-papers/conference-proceedings/proceedings2001 | pages = 205–212 }}</ref> and Jordan Louviere (University of Iowa) who invented and developed choice-based approaches to conjoint analysis and related techniques such as [[best–worst scaling]].
Today it is used in many of the social sciences and applied sciences including [[marketing]], [[product management]], and [[operations research]]. It is used frequently in testing customer acceptance of [[new product development|new product designs]], in assessing the appeal of [[advertising|advertisements]] and in [[service design]]. It has been used in [[positioning (marketing)|product positioning]], but there are some who raise problems with this application of conjoint analysis.
Conjoint analysis techniques may also be referred to as multiattribute compositional modelling, discrete choice modelling, or stated preference research, and is part of a broader set of trade-off analysis tools used for systematic analysis of decisions. These tools include Brand-Price Trade-Off, [[Simalto]], and mathematical approaches such as [[Analytic hierarchy process|AHP]],<ref>{{cite journal|title=A comparison of analytic hierarchy process and conjoint analysis methods in assessing treatment alternatives for stroke rehabilitation|vauthors=Ijzerman MJ, van Til JA, Bridges JF|year=212|pmid=22185216|doi=10.2165/11587140-000000000-00000|volume=5|journal=Patient|pages=45–56}}</ref> [[evolutionary algorithms]] or [[rule-developing experimentation]].
== Conjoint design == A product or service area is described in terms of a number of attributes. For example, a television may have attributes of screen size, screen format, brand, price and so on. Each attribute can then be broken down into a number of levels. For instance, levels for screen format may be LED, LCD, or Plasma.
Respondents would be shown a set of products, prototypes, mock-ups, or pictures created from a combination of levels from all or some of the constituent attributes and asked to choose from, rank or rate the products they are shown. Each example is similar enough that consumers will see them as close substitutes, but dissimilar enough that respondents can clearly determine a preference. Each example is composed of a unique combination of product features. The data may consist of individual ratings, rank orders, or preferences among alternative combinations.
As the number of combinations of attributes and levels increases the number of potential profiles increases exponentially. Consequently, [[fractional factorial design]] is commonly used to reduce the number of profiles that have to be evaluated, while ensuring enough data are available for statistical analysis, resulting in a carefully controlled set of "profiles" for the respondent to consider.
== Types == The earliest forms of conjoint analysis were what are known as Full Profile studies, in which a small set of attributes (typically 4 to 5) are used to create profiles that are shown to respondents, often on individual cards. Respondents then rank or rate these profiles. Using relatively simple [[Dummy variable (statistics)|dummy variable]] [[regression analysis]] the implicit utilities for the levels can be calculated. Two drawbacks were seen in these early designs.
Firstly, the number of attributes in use was heavily restricted. With large numbers of attributes, the consideration task for respondents becomes too large and even with fractional factorial designs the number of profiles for evaluation can increase rapidly. In order to use more attributes (up to 30), hybrid conjoint techniques were developed. The main alternative was to do some form of self-explication (rating of separate components) before the conjoint tasks and some form of adaptive computer-aided choice over the profiles to be shown.
The second drawback was that the task itself was unrealistic and did not link directly to behavioural theory. In real-life situations, the task would be some form of actual choice between alternatives rather than the more artificial ranking and rating originally used. Jordan Louviere pioneered an approach that used only a choice task which became the basis of [[choice-based conjoint analysis]] and [[discrete choice analysis]]. This stated preference research is linked to [[econometric modeling]] and can be linked to [[revealed preference]] where choice models are calibrated on the basis of real rather than survey data. Originally choice-based conjoint analysis was unable to provide individual level utilities as it aggregated choices across a market. This made it unsuitable for market segmentation studies. With newer hierarchical [[Bayesian probability|Bayesian]] analysis techniques, individual level utilities can be imputed back to provide individual level data.
== Information collection == Data for conjoint analysis are most commonly gathered through a market research survey, although conjoint analysis can also be applied to a carefully designed [[configurator]] or data from an appropriately designed [[test market]] experiment. Market research rules of thumb apply with regard to statistical sample size and accuracy when designing conjoint analysis interviews.
The length of the research questionnaire depends on the number of attributes to be assessed and the method of conjoint analysis in use. A typical adaptive conjoint questionnaire with 20-25 attributes may take more than 30 minutes to complete{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}. Choice based conjoint, by using a smaller profile set distributed across the sample as a whole may be completed in less than 15 minutes. Choice exercises may be displayed as a store front type layout or in some other simulated shopping environment.
==Analysis== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2017}} [[File:Sample-output-of-conjoint-analysis.png|thumb|Sample output of conjoint analysis with application to marketing (a choice-based experiment on ice-cream performed on [http://www.conjoint.online/ Conjoint.ly])]] Depending on the type of model, different econometric and statistical methods can be used to estimate utility functions. These utility functions indicate the perceived value of the feature and how sensitive consumer perceptions and preferences are to changes in product features. The actual estimation procedure will depend on the design of the task and profiles for respondents, in the type of specification, and the scale of measure for preferences (it can be ratio, ranking, choice) which can have a limited range or not. For rated full profile tasks, [[linear regression]] may be appropriate, for choice based tasks, [[maximum likelihood estimation]], usually with [[logistic regression]] are typically used. The original methods were monotonic analysis of variance or linear programming techniques, but contemporary marketing research practice has shifted towards choice-based models using multinomial logit, mixed versions of this model, and other refinements. [[Bayesian estimator]]s are also very popular. Hierarchical Bayesian procedures are nowadays relatively popular as well.
==Advantages and disadvantages== ===Advantages=== * estimates psychological tradeoffs that consumers make when evaluating several attributes together * measures preferences at the individual level * uncovers real or hidden drivers which may not be apparent to the respondent themselves * realistic choice or shopping task * able to use physical objects * if appropriately designed, the ability to model interactions between attributes can be used to develop needs based segmentation
===Disadvantages=== * designing conjoint studies can be complex * with too many options, respondents resort to simplification strategies * difficult to use for product positioning research because there is no procedure for converting perceptions about actual features to perceptions about a reduced set of underlying features * respondents are unable to articulate attitudes toward new categories, or may feel forced to think about issues they would otherwise not give much thought to * poorly designed studies may over-value emotional/preference variables and undervalue concrete variables * does not take into account the number items per purchase so it can give a poor reading of market share
==Practical applications==
===Market research===
One practical application of conjoint analysis in business analysis is given by the following example: A real estate developer is interested in building a high rise apartment complex near an urban Ivy League university. To ensure the success of the project, a market research firm is hired to conduct focus groups with current students. Students are segmented by academic year (freshman, upper classmen, graduate studies) and amount of financial aid received. Study participants are given a series of index cards. Each card has 6 attributes to describe the potential building project (proximity to campus, cost, telecommunication packages, laundry options, floor plans, and security features offered). The estimated cost to construct the building described on each card is equivalent. Participants are asked to order the cards from least to most appealing. This forced ranking exercise will indirectly reveal the participants' priorities and preferences. Multi-variate [[regression analysis]] may be used to determine the strength of preferences across target market segments.
===Litigation===
Federal courts in the United States have allowed expert witnesses to use conjoint analysis to support their opinions on the damages that an infringer of a patent should pay to compensate the patent holder for violating its rights.<ref>Cornell University v. Hewlett-Packard Co., 609 F. Supp. 2d 279 (N.D.N.Y. 2009); Sentius Int'l, LLC v. Microsoft Corp., No. 5:13-cv-00825, 2015 WL 331939 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 23, 2015).</ref> Nonetheless, legal scholars have noted that the Federal Circuit's jurisprudence on the use of conjoint analysis in patent-damages calculations remains in a formative stage.<ref>J. Gregory Sidak & Jeremy O. Skog, ''Using Conjoint Analysis to Apportion Patent Damages'', (Criterion Economics Working Paper, Jan. 29, 2016), https://www.criterioneconomics.com/using-conjoint-analysis-to-apportion-patent-damages.html.</ref>

'''Dominique Prieur''' (born 1949) is a French military officer who was convicted of manslaughter over her part in the [[sinking of the Rainbow Warrior]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10656664|title=French Expat Recalls NZ Bombing|last=Astier|first=Henri|date=8 July 2005|work=BBC News|access-date=4 May 2016|via=}}[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4637897.stm <!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Prieur was also the first woman French [[Espionage|secret agent]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/attack-on-boat-still-haunts-secret-agent-1587188.html|title=Attack on Boat Still Haunts Secret Agent|last=Dejevsky|first=Mary|date=18 June 1995|work=Independent|access-date=4 May 2016|via=}}</ref>
== Biography == Prieur joined the military in 1974 and was recruited as a secret agent in August 1977.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.liberation.fr/portrait/1995/07/07/dominique-prieur-l-agente-secrete-refait-surface-et-ecrit-en-1985-la-dgse-la-charge-de-preparer-l-at_138226|title=Dominique Prieur. L'agente secrète refait surface et écrit. En 1985, la DGSE la charge de préparer l'attentat contre le «Rainbow Warrior». Dix ans plus tard, l'ancienne|last=Guisnel|first=Jean|date=7 July 1995|work=Liberation|language=French|access-date=4 May 2016|via=}}</ref>
=== Sinking of the ''Rainbow Warrior'' ===
Prieur worked in the intelligence-gathering and evaluation wing of the French Secret Service, the Direction Générale de la Sécurité Extérieure ([[DGSE]]). She was an expert in European peace organisations and was the controller for [[Christine Cabon]].<ref name=":5" /> Cabon was posted to [[Auckland]] in April 1985, where she infiltrated the [[Greenpeace Aotearoa New Zealand|Greenpeace]] office and gathered information for Prieur and her fellow agent [[Alain Mafart]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/about/history/the-bombing-of-the-rainbow-war/rainbow/|title=A beret, a bottle of Beaujolais and a baguette|website=Greenpeace International|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref> In July 1985, Prieur and Marfart entered New Zealand from Corsica on Swiss passports issued to their aliases Sophie and Alain Turenge, a newlywed couple on honeymoon.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /> Their instructions were to sink the ''Rainbow Warrior'' as the French government suspected that it would be used to protest the upcoming nuclear tests at [[Mururoa atoll]] in the South Pacific.<ref name=":4" /> Prieur's responsibilities were the logistics of the operation, and the evacuation of the agents from the country after the bombing had taken place.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=4850|title=Saboteur spills the French beans|date=2000-06-30|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref>
Prieur and Marfart delivered [[limpet mine]]<nowiki/>s to two [[Frogman|frogmen]] to plant on the ship's hull on the night of 10 July 1985.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/defence/news/article.cfm?c_id=32&objectid=3007440|title=The day Operation Satanic came to NZ|date=2002-12-03|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref> The explosions sank the vessel and killed photographer [[Fernando Pereira]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" />
They were arrested by [[New Zealand police]] within 30 hours of the bombing, and o<nowiki/>riginally charged with Pereira's murder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://my.christchurchcitylibraries.com/rainbow-warrior/|title=Rainbow Warrior bombing|website=my.christchurchcitylibraries.com|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref> Prieur was transferred to [[Christchurch]] Women's Prison and held there awaiting trial.<ref name=":7" /> Prieur pleaded guilty to charges of manslaughter and wilful damage in the Auckland District Court, and was sentenced to ten years imprisonment on 22 November 1985.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/profile/Susan%20Barnum/clipnumber/38947/|title=Greenpeace Bombers|last=|first=|date=22 November 1985|work=Logansport Pharos Tribume|access-date=4 May 2016|via=Newspaper Archive}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/rainbow-warrior-30th-anniversary-of-bombing-by-french-commandos-in-auckland-new-zealand-on-july-10-1985/news-story/ef4f785ccbc7c0bdeb60a06719a8471b|title=Rainbow Warrior: 30th anniversary of bombing by French commandos in Auckland, New Zealand, on July 10, 1985|last=|first=|date=10 July 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=9 May 2016}}</ref> After serious political pressure from France and her allies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10656635 |title=At the end of the Rainbow - National - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2014-01-13}}</ref> the New Zealand government agreed to a [[United Nations]] arbitration ruling in July 1986 that saw the pair transferred to French custody on the island of [[Hao (French Polynesia)|Hao]] in French Polynesia.
Prieur's husband, Joel Prieur, an employee of the Defense Department, was posted to Hao shortly after she was exiled there.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/profile/Susan%20Barnum/clipnumber/38949/|title=France Ends Agent's Exile|last=|first=|date=7 May 1988|work=Cedar Rapids Gazette|access-date=4 May 2016|via=Newspaper Archive}}</ref> On 6 May 1988 she was returned to France because she was pregnant, and was heralded as a national hero.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/profile/Susan_Barnum/clipnumber/38952/|title=Spy: French Leader Ordered Sinking|last=|first=|date=11 July 2005|work=Daily Herald Suburban Chicago|access-date=4 May 2016|via=Newspaper Archive}}</ref> She never returned to Hao.
Although a UN Arbitration panel found that France had breached its obligation to New Zealand several times by removing the agents from Hao, and failing to return them, it rejected the claim by New Zealand to have Mafart and Prieur returned because the term they should have spent there had already lapsed.
=== Later career ===
In 1989, Prieur was promoted to Major,<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3LtFS3rl9MC&lpg=PA304&dq=%22Dominique%20Prieur%22&pg=PA304#v=onepage&q=%22Dominique%20Prieur%22&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Cold War Espionage, Spies, and Secret Operations|last=|first=|publisher=Enigma Books|year=2009|isbn=9781929631759|editor-last=Trahair|editor-first=Richard C. S.|edition=revised|location=|pages=304|editor-last2=Miller|editor-first2=Robert L.}}</ref> and by 2002 she had been promoted to the rank of [[Commandant (rank)|Commandant]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=News of the Swimmer Reaches Shore: A Guide to French Usage|last=O'Brien|first=Gregory|publisher=Victoria University Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-86473-532-4|location=Wellington, New Zealand|pages=}}</ref>
Prieur published a book ''"Agent secrète"'' (''Secret Agent'') in 1995 concerning her role in the bombing. With regards to the death of Pereira, she wrote "We were terrified and appalled ... We hadn't come here to kill anyone."<ref name=":3" />
In 2005, Prieur and Marfart appealed to the [[Supreme Court of New Zealand|New Zealand Supreme Court]] to stop footage of their guilty pleas being shown on television.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=20060927B012114112&site=ehost-live|title=Ship Bombers Lose TV Appeal|last=|first=|date=27 September 2006|work=Gold Coast Bulletin|subscription=yes|access-date=4 May 2016|via=EBSCO}}</ref> The supreme court allowed the footage to go on the air.<ref name=":1" />
In 2009, Prieur was hired as the director of human resources for the [[Paris Fire Brigade]], a unit of the [[French Army]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10656664|title=Rainbow Warrior: Where Are They Now?|last=|first=|date=5 July 2016|work=New Zealand Herald|access-date=4 May 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>Staff (4 January 2009) "Fresh Start for Saboteur" ''Sunday Mail'' (South Australia) p. 29</ref>

{{Infobox person |image = Edward R. Bacon by Anders Zorn.jpg |caption = Zorn's 1897 portrait of Mr. Bacon |image_size = 220px |birth_date = {{birth date|1848|11|22}} |birth_place = [[Le Roy, New York]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1915|12|02|1848|11|22}} |death_place = [[Baltimore]], Maryland |other_names = E.R. Bacon |occupation = Lawyer, financier }}
'''Edward Rathbone Bacon''' (born in Le Roy, New York on November 22, 1848) was president of a railroad, lawyer and financier. His father was David Rinaldo Bacon and his mother was Elizabeth Rathbone. He had four siblings, Walter Rathbone, Lathrup Rufus, John Ganson, and Mary Sibley Bacon. Bacon never married or had children. Bacon served as the vice-president of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and as the president of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad. He also worked as a lawyer and financier.<ref name="Railway Age Gazette">{{cite book|title=Railway Age Gazette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j39NAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1110|year=1915|publisher=Railway Age Gazette, Incorporated|page=1110}}</ref><ref name="timesmachine.nytimes.com">[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/12/12/104018253.html?pageNumber=40 ''New York Times'' December 12, 1915]</ref> Bacon died on December 2, 1915 in Baltimore, Maryland as a result of an appendicitis operation he had a week earlier.<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915">[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/12/03/106733508.html?pageNumber=11 ''New York Times'' December 3, 1915]</ref>
Bacon's main residence was 247 5th Avenue, New York, where he lived with his brother Walter and his sister-in-law [[Virginia P. Bacon]].<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/> He is also reported to have lived in Buffalo for a time.<ref>{{cite news |jstor=25588752 |newspaper=American Art News |date= December 11, 1915}}</ref> Bacon worked out of an office at 2 Wall Street in New York.<ref name="American Publishers' Association">{{cite book|title=Herringshaw's American Blue-book of Biography: Prominent Americans of ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4IxIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA45|year=1914|publisher=American Publishers' Association|page=45}}</ref> He traveled often to Europe, which is where he purchased many of the works that made up his extensive art collection.<ref>''Memorial Catalog of Paintings by Old and Modern Masters, Collected by Edward R. Bacon'', Prepared by James B. Townsend and W. Stanton Howard (New York: The Devinne Press, 1919).</ref><ref>''Memorial Catalogue of Chinese Art Objects, Including Porcelains, Potteries, Jades, Bronzes, and Cloisonne enamels, Collected by Edward R. Bacon'', Prepared by James B. Townsend and W. Stanton Howard. Introduction by John Getz (New York: The Devinne Press, 1919), xi.</ref> He was included in the list of notable people arriving from Europe to New York City in the ''New York Times'' on October 13, 1895.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1895/10/13/102477157.html?pageNumber=17 ''New York Times'' October 13, 1895.]</ref>
==Career==
Edward Bacon was educated at Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, New Hampshire.<ref name="Railway Age Gazette"/> In 1869 he was admitted to the Bar in Buffalo, New York.<ref name="LeonardMarquis1907">{{cite book|author1=John William Leonard|author2=Albert Nelson Marquis|title=Who's who in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-UUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA65|year=1907|publisher=Marquis Who's Who|page=65}}</ref> Bacon lived and worked in Buffalo for a time, where he "achieved success as a lawyer."<ref name="New York Times February 2, 1896">[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1896/02/02/108221572.html?pageNumber=2 ''New York Times'' February 2, 1896]</ref> In around 1881 he moved to New York City and became Vice-President of the Cincinnati, Washington, & Baltimore Railroad.<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/><ref name="New York Times February 2, 1896"/> From 1890 to 1902 he was the President of the Cincinnati, Washington, and Baltimore Railroad, which was later called the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Trains/ICC valuations/Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad|Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad]]. In fact, "it was through his efforts that the Cincinnati, Washington & Baltimore branch of the road was built," according to Bacon's ''New York Times'' obituary.<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/> In 1896 he was appointed as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]].
Bacon counseled various railway companies in law matters before and during his posts at Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.<ref name="Railway Age Gazette"/> In 1881 he joined the firm Field, Dorsheimer, Deyo, and Bacon.<ref name="New York Times February 2, 1896"/> The companies he counseled include [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]] Company, [[Consol Energy|Consolidated Coal Company]], [[Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railway|West Virginia and Pittsburgh Railroad Company]], and [[Vicksburg, Shreveport and Pacific Railway|Vicksburg, Shreveport & Pacific Railroad Company]].<ref name="LeonardMarquis1907"/> Bacon was known as "one of the best-known financiers in the country."<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/>
Additional posts include director of the Farmer's Loan and Trust Company, director of the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company in New York, director of Knickerbocker Apartment Company, director of the Kansas City Southern Railway, and of the Cincinnati, Hamilton, and Dayton Railway.<ref name="Railway Age Gazette"/><ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Electric Railway Journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kKdMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1016|year=1917|publisher=McGraw Hill Publishing Company|page=1016}}</ref>
==Art collection== Edward Bacon owned an extensive collection of [[Old Master]] paintings and Chinese art objects. He was private about his collecting, and he "never consented to lend pictures from his collection for public exhibition." <ref name="Modern Masters 1919">''Memorial Catalog of Paintings by Old and Modern Masters'', Collected by Edward R. Bacon, Prepared by James B. Townsend and W. Stanton Howard (New York: The Devinne Press, 1919).</ref> An article in ''American Art News'' published after Bacon's death stated that "It is passing strange that no journal, in the many obituaries of Edward R. Bacon that have been widely published as of late, has even alluded to him as an art collector, and yet he was well known to the art world as an art lover and collector of note."<ref name="jstor.org">{{cite news |jstor=25588750|newspaper=American Art News|date=December 11, 1915|volume=14|number=10}}</ref>
Bacon began collecting about 25 years before his death.<ref name="jstor.org"/> It started in an "unostentatious way...rather as an accessory to contribute in some dignified way to the appearance of his home.<ref>''Memorial Catalogue of Chinese Art Objects, Including Porcelains, Potteries, Jades, Bronzes, and Cloisonne enamels'', Collected by Edward R. Bacon, Prepared by James B. Townsend and W. Stanton Howard. Introduction by John Getz (New York: The Devinne Press, 1919), xi.</ref> Bacon was generally interested in collecting works by the Old Masters and Chinese art objects. He was interested in "the quaint and loveable" and preferred "light and gay" pictures, and anything "full of vivacity."<ref name="Modern Masters 1919"/> He first collected paintings from well-known artists of his day, and then moved on to French 18th century works. Next, he began collecting 18th century English portraits. Later, he turned to the Italian primitives, a group "that does not attract the uncultivated."<ref name="Modern Masters 1919"/> In reference to his collection of Chinese art, John Getz wrote that Edward Bacon was "among those connoisseurs who long ago recognized the beauty and intrinsic worth of Chinese art as manifested in ceramics, cloisonné, bronze…"<ref name="Chinese Art Objects 1919">''Memorial Catalogue of Chinese Art Objects, Including Porcelains, Potteries, Jades, Bronzes, and Cloisonne enamels, Collected by Edward R. Bacon'', Prepared by James B. Townsend and W. Stanton Howard. Introduction by John Getz (New York: The Devinne Press, 1919).</ref> Getz also mentioned a "reliable agent abroad" who aided Bacon in discovering and purchasing these artworks. He could possibly be referring to Mr. Eugene Fischhof of Paris, who is known to have worked with Bacon.<ref name="jstor.org"/> Bacon kept his collection in the Upper East Side apartment he shared with his brother and sister-in-law.<ref name="jstor.org"/>
Notable works in Bacon's collection included:
*''The Four Seasons'' by [[François Boucher]] *''Portrait of Mrs. Hart'' by [[Henry Raeburn]] *''Portrait of Rigaud'' by [[Jean-Antoine Watteau]] *''Señorita Tuzo'' by [[Francisco Goya]]
In 1919 a catalog detailing all works in Bacon's collection was published in limited quantity.<ref name="Modern Masters 1919"/><ref name="Chinese Art Objects 1919"/> The catalog's creation was the idea of his sister-in-law, [[Virginia P. Bacon]], though she did not live to see the two-volume catalog published. An ''American Art News'' reporter wrote, in a review of the books, that "The catalogs have a literary character and differ from the ordinary sale and collection catalogs in that they give interesting pen pictures of the works listed and illustrated, and copious footnotes."<ref>{{cite news|jstor= 25589666 |newspaper=American Art News |title=Review: John Zoffany: His Life and Works |date=June 26, 1920|volume=18|number=36|page=4}}</ref>
==Club memberships and society presence== [[File:Edward R. Bacon.png|thumb|Edward R. Bacon, as pictured in the ''Railway Age Gazette'' obituary]]
Bacon was a member of many New York clubs, including the Manhattan Club, Union Club, the Metropolitan Art Museum, the Tuxedo Club, the New York Yacht Club, and the Racquet and Tennis Club.<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/><ref>{{cite journal | jstor=40303215 |title=Members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art |publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art |date=March 1, 1905|number=35}}</ref> He was a member of the Academy of Political Science in New York in 1912.<ref>{{cite journal |jstor=1193326 |title= List of Members |journal=Proceedings of the Academy of Political Science in the City of New York |date=October 1912|volume=3|number=1}}</ref> Bacon also held box 18 at the Metropolitan Opera on odd Mondays.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=20543696| title=List of Box-Holders at the Opera |journal=The Lotus Magazine|date=December 1915 |volume=7 |number=3 |pp=139–142}}</ref> He was a member of several automobile-centered clubs, such as the Automobile of America, and the Royal Automobile Club of England.<ref>{{cite book|title=International Motor Cyclopaedia, Sport, Industry and Trade. ...: Year Book ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xi06AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA7|year=1908|publisher=E.E. Schwarzkopf|page=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Royal Automobile Club Year Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qs5AAQAAIAAJ|year=1914|publisher=Royal Automobile Club.|page=56}}</ref>
In addition, Bacon was a well-known man in both the United States and England. He was included in ''Who's Who in America'' in 1907, in ''Herringshaw's American Blue Book of Biography'' in 1914, and in ''Who's Who in New York City and State'' in 1914.<ref name="American Publishers' Association"/><ref name="LeonardMarquis1907"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Who's who in New York City and State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5exHAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA28|year=1914|publisher=L.R. Hamersly Company|page=28}}</ref> In 1913 an article in the ''New York Times'' states that Edward Bacon could not attend a large charity ball in London, as he had "left the Ritz" and was "sailing for New York" after having recovered from an automobile accident.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/01/26/100250616.html?pageNumber=38 ''New York Times'' January 26, 1913]</ref>
==Death and estate== Bacon died at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland on December 2, 1915. His death was due to complications after an operation for appendicitis.<ref name="New York Times December 3, 1915"/> Sources estimate that his estate was worth $2,000,000 at the time of his death.<ref>{{cite journal |jstor=25588759 |journal=American Art News |date=December 18, 1915}}</ref> He made bequests totaling around $1,000,000 to relatives an employees, and specified that the rest of the estate, including his collection of paintings, be shared equally between his brother Walter R. Bacon and his sister-in-law Virginia P. Bacon.<ref name="timesmachine.nytimes.com"/> Bequests included $400,000 to both his sister Mrs. Mary B. Allen and his brother John G. Bacon, and his cousins and nieces each received $50,000 and $40,000, respectively. He also bequeathed varying sums to his cook, secretary, valet, footman, and maids.<ref name="timesmachine.nytimes.com"/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Eliodoro Matte |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Eliodoro Matte Larraín |birth_date = {{birth date and age |1945|11|05|df=yes}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = Santiago, Chile |nationality = Chilean |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = [[Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile]]
[[Booth School of Business]] |occupation = President, [[CMPC (company)|CMPC]] |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = US$2.7 [[billion]] (October 2015) |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Pilar Capdevila |partner = |children = 3 |parents = [[Eliodoro Matte Ossa]] |relations = [[Bernardo Matte]] (brother)
[[Patricia Matte]] (sister) |website = }} '''Eliodoro Matte Larraín''' (born 5 November 1945) is a Chilean [[billionaire]] businessman, president of the Chilean forestry and paper company [[CMPC (company)|CMPC]], that he inherited from his father. Matte was born on 5 November 1945, the son of [[Eliodoro Matte Ossa]]. He took on a bachelor's degree in a civil industrial engineering from the University of Chile (without graduating),{{cite web|url=http://www.quepasa.cl/articulo/ojos-de-la-llave/2017/02/el-titulo-de-ingeniero-civil-de-la-u-de-chile-que-e-matte-no-posee.shtml/ |title=El título de Ingeniero Civil de la U. de Chile que Eliodoro Matte no posee Revista Qué Pasa |publisher=Quepasa.cl |date= |accessdate=1 April 2017}} followed by an MBA from the [[Booth School of Business]], University of Chicago.{{cite web|title=Eliodoro Matte Larraín |url=http://www.colbun.cl/en/inversionistas/gobierno-corporativo/directorio/eliodoro-matte/ |website=colbun |accessdate=22 October 2015 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He is chairman of the think tank [[Centro de Estudios Públicos]] (CEP). As of October 2015, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated his net worth at US$2.7 billion.{{cite web|title=Eliodoro Matte|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eliodoro-matte/?list=billionaires|website=Forbes|accessdate=22 October 2015}} He is married to Pilar Capdevila,{{cite web|title=Eliodoro Matte Larraín|url=http://www.cecs.cl/website/index.php/en/advisory-committee/673-eliodoro-matte-larrain|website=cecs|accessdate=23 October 2015}} and they have three children: Eliodoro Matte Capdevila, Jorge Matte Capdevila, and María del Pilar Matte Capdevila.{{cite web|title=Main Shareholder|url=http://www.colbun.cl/en/inversionistas/gobierno-corporativo/propiedad-y-control/|website=colbun}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matte, Eliodoro }} [[Category:1940s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chilean businesspeople]] [[Category:Chilean billionaires]] [[Category:Matte family|Elidoro]] [[Category:Pontifical Catholic University of Chile alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago Booth School of Business alumni]]

page.title: Endowment Fund for the Rehabilitation of Tigray

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Endowment Fund for the Rehabilitation of Tigray | native_name = ንዳውመንት ፈንድ ፎር ዘ ሪሃብልቴሽን ፎር ትግራይ | native_name_lang = am | industry = Textiles, Transportation, Agriculture, Construction, Mining, Construction Materials | founded = 1995 | area_served = [[Ethiopia]] }}The Endowment Fund for the Rehabilitation of Tigray (EFFORT) is a conglomerate of businesses factories mainly based in [[Tigray Region]], [[Ethiopia]] in order to improve the local economy that was devastated by the [[Ethiopian Civil War]] and the [[1983–1985 famine in Ethiopia|1983–1985 famine]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Rethinking business and politics in Ethiopia: The role of EFFORT, the Endowment Fund for the Rehabilitation of Tigray|last=Vaughan|first=Sarah|last2=Gebremichael|first2=Mesfin|publisher=Overseas Development Institute|year=2011|isbn=|location=London|pages=6–61}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Young|first=John|date=March 1997|title=Development and Change in Post-Revolutionary Tigray|jstor=162055|journal=The Journal of Modern African Studies|volume=35|pages=85–86}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+EFFORT's major companies are:<ref name=":1" /> !Name !Industry |- |Mesebo Cement/Building | rowspan="5" |Construction |- |Sur Construction |- |Mesfin Engineering |- |Maichew Particleboard |- |Romanat Packaging |- |Almeda Textile/Garment | rowspan="3" |Textiles |- |Sheba Leather |- |National Geotextile/Gabion |- |Guna Trading | rowspan="5" |Agriculture |- |Hiwot Agriculture |- |Bruh Tesfa Irrigation |- |Raya Field Agroprocessing |- |Abergelle Livestock |- |Ezana Mining | rowspan="2" |Mining |- |Saba Stones |- |TransEthiopia |Transportation |- |Addis Pharmaceuticals |Pharmaceuticals |} '''Note:''' EFFORT only has a 49 percent stake in Addis Pharmaceuticals, the majority holder being Mulugeta Guade Mengiste (a large [[Amharas|Amhara]] private capitalist).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Milkias|first=Paulos|date=August 2018|title=Ethiopia, The TPLF and Roots of the 2001 Political Tremor|url=|journal=International Conference on African Development Archives|volume=|pages=18|via=}}</ref> EFFORT no longer owns Selam Horticulture, Dimma Honey, and Raya Field Agroprocessing.<ref name=":1" />
